review.title: Fuzzy Model on Human Emotions Recognition
review.abstract: This paper discusses a fuzzy model for multi-level human emotions recognition by computer systems through keyboard keystrokes, mouse and touchscreen interactions. This model can also be used to detect the other possible emotions at the time of recognition. Accuracy measurements of human emotions by the fuzzy model are discussed through two methods; the first is accuracy analysis and the second is false positive rate analysis. This fuzzy model detects more emotions, but on the other hand, for some of emotions, a lower accuracy was obtained with the comparison with the non-fuzzy human emotions detection methods. This system was trained and tested by Support Vector Machine (SVM) to recognize the users' emotions. Overall, this model represents a closer similarity between human brain detection of emotions and computer systems.

sections.heading: 2 Methodology

sections.heading: 2.1 Analysis of Emotions
sections.text: Here, only eight basic emotions were discussed, which are joy, anticipation, anger, disgust, sadness, surprise, fear and acceptance. However, some similar change patterns were found among some emotions. Basically, both negative and positive emotions have similar change patterns, but between these basic emotions, some of ISBN: 978-1-61804-156-2 78they are very close to each other. For example, disgust and anger have a similar change pattern with each other, and sadness is closer to them compared to the other emotions. On the other hand, acceptance and anticipation have very similar change patterns with each other. As can be seen, these emotions are in the same group in terms of positive and negative emotions. sections.heading: 2.2 Fuzzy Human Emotions Recognition
sections.text: In order to detect the emotions, the system was trained and tested by the Support Vector Machine (SVM) to detect the emotions of the users. The above results are now used in the evaluation for multi-stage emotion recognition from 0 to 4, and it is also attempted to detect multiple emotions at each stage of the detection process. Table 7 shows the end result of the detection after applying the blurred logic concept to detect every emotion by SVM in a range from 0 to 4. The following table shows a lower accuracy in detecting some multi-level emotions compared to the other non-blurred methods, as the number of available states has been increased to detect the emotion, but the accuracy in the emotion of Nervous has been increased. Applying the blurred model to human emotion detection systems represents a more natural report on human emotions, which includes all possible emotions and their levels and strengths. This report may not be as accurate as the detection we had for classical emotions, but it is more reliable for the detection of individual emotions.

sections.heading: 2.3 Fuzzy Model on Human Emotions Recognition: Discussion
sections.text: The above data and classification were used as a blurred model in our human emotion recognition system. Accuracy of emotion recognition was assessed on the basis of two different aspects: the first aspect assessed whether the name of the emotion or emotion detected was correct or not, and the second aspect assessed the system on the percentage of emotion detected [14, 15]. For example, consider a user with two emotions of joy - 50% and fear - 20%. In the first aspect of the evaluation, if the system was able to detect joy and fear, the evaluation was carried out successfully; in the second aspect, however, not only joy and fear should be correctly detected, but also the detected level of other emotions would be taken into account in the accuracy of the system [16]. This model was tested on a human emotion detection system that operated on the basis of positive keystroke dynamics, mouse movements and touch screen interactions.

sections.heading: 3 Conclusion
sections.text: This research proposed a new, blurred model, presenting a new solution based on statistics and probabilities for the recognition of human emotions in order to overcome some of the problems in this field of research. This model recognized the other possible emotions at the same time and worked more naturally by recognizing emotions in terms of level and not by a discrete name of emotion. The human emotion recognition system on which this model was implemented was able to achieve up to 5% higher accuracy in the recognition method, and a maximum 16.7% false positive rate for the recognition of the level of emotions. This model can be extended, improved and even integrated into different systems. Future research will deal with the recognition of human emotions by extracted models for each region of the world and then compare the accuracy and false positive rates of these different regions.
